name: Game.TwoD

aliases.name: RenderConfig
aliases.comment:
This is used by all the functions below, it represents all the shared state needed to render stuff.
If you don't use sprite animations you can use `0` for the time parameter.
aliases.type: { time : Float , size : ( Int, Int ) , camera : Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera }

values.name: render
values.type: Game.TwoD.RenderConfig -> List Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable -> Html.Html x

values.name: renderCentered
values.comment: Same as `render`, but wrapped in a div and nicely centered on the page using flexbox
values.type: Game.TwoD.RenderConfig -> List Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable -> Html.Html x

values.name: renderCenteredWithOptions
values.comment:
Same as above, but you can specify attributes for the container div and the canvas.

    renderCenteredWithOptions
        containerAttributes
        canvasAttributes
        renderConfig
        renderables
values.type: List (Html.Attribute msg) -> List (Html.Attribute msg) -> Game.TwoD.RenderConfig -> List Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable -> Html.Html msg

values.name: renderWithOptions
values.comment:
Same as above, but you can specify additional attributes that will be passed to the canvas element.
A useful trick to save some GPU processing at the cost of image quality is
to use a smaller `size` argument and than scale the canvas with CSS. e.g.

    renderWithOptions [style [("width", "800px"), ("height", "600px")]]
        { time = time, size = (400, 300), camera = camera }
        (World.render model.world)
values.type: List (Html.Attribute msg) -> Game.TwoD.RenderConfig -> List Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable -> Html.Html msg

name: Game.TwoD.Render

aliases.name: MakeUniformsFunc
aliases.comment: Just an alias, needed when you want to use customFragment
aliases.type: { cameraProj : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 , time : Float , transform : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 } -> { a | cameraProj : Math.Matrix4.Mat4, transform : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 }

types.name: BasicShape
types.comment: A representation of a basic shape to use when rendering a ColoredShape

types.name: Renderable
types.comment:
A representation of something that can be rendered.
To actually render a `Renderable` onto a web page use the `Game.TwoD.*` functions

values.name: animatedSprite
values.comment:
An animated sprite. `bottomLeft` and `topRight` define a sub area from a texture
where the animation frames are located. It's a normalized coordinate from 0 to 1.

TODO: picture!
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float2, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, bottomLeft : Game.Helpers.Float2, topRight : Game.Helpers.Float2, numberOfFrames : Int, duration : Float } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: animatedSpriteWithOptions
values.comment: the same with rotation
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, bottomLeft : Game.Helpers.Float2, topRight : Game.Helpers.Float2, rotation : Float, pivot : Game.Helpers.Float2, numberOfFrames : Int, duration : Float } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: animatedSpriteZ
values.comment: The same with 3d position
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, bottomLeft : Game.Helpers.Float2, topRight : Game.Helpers.Float2, numberOfFrames : Int, duration : Float } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: circle
values.comment: BasicShape constructor for a circle
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape

values.name: customFragment
values.comment:
This allows you to write your own custom fragment shader.
To learn about writing shaders, I recommend [this free book](https://thebookofshaders.com/00/).

The type signature may look terrifying,
but this is still easier than using veryCustom or using WebGL directly.
It handles the vertex shader for you, e.g. your object will appear at the expected location once rendered.

For the fragment shader, you have the `vec2 varying vcoord;` variable available,
which can be used to sample a texture (`texture2D(texture, vcoord);`).
It's a vector that goes from (0,0) to (1,1)

The `MakeUniformsFunc` allows you to pass along any additional uniforms you may need.
In practice, this might look something like this:

    makeUniforms { cameraProj, transform, time } =
        { cameraProj = cameraProj, transform = transform, time = time, myUniform = someVector }

    render =
        customFragment makeUniforms
            { fragmentShader = frag, position = p, size = s, rotation = 0, pivot = ( 0, 0 ) }

    frag =
        [glsl|

    precision mediump float;

    varying vec2 vcoord;
    uniform vec2 myUniform;

    void main () {
      gl_FragColor = vcoord.yx + myUniform;
    }
    |]

Don't pass the time along if your shader doesn't need it.

Here is a small example that draws a circle:
<https://ellie-app.com/LSTb2NnkDWa1/0>
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.MakeUniformsFunc u -> { b | fragmentShader : WebGL.Shader {} { u | cameraProj : Math.Matrix4.Mat4, transform : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }, pivot : Game.Helpers.Float2, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, rotation : Float, size : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: manuallyManagedAnimatedSpriteWithOptions
values.comment: The same as animated sprite, but you control what frame to display.
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, bottomLeft : Game.Helpers.Float2, topRight : Game.Helpers.Float2, rotation : Float, pivot : Game.Helpers.Float2, numberOfFrames : Int, currentFrame : Int } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: parallaxScroll
values.comment:
Used for scrolling backgrounds.
This probably wont satisfy all possible needs for a scrolling background,
but it can give you something that looks nice quickly.
values.type: { o | scrollSpeed : Game.Helpers.Float2, z : Float, tileWH : Game.Helpers.Float2, texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: parallaxScrollWithOptions
values.comment: Same but with an offset parameter that you can use to position the background.
values.type: { o | scrollSpeed : Game.Helpers.Float2, z : Float, tileWH : Game.Helpers.Float2, offset : Game.Helpers.Float2, texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: rectangle
values.comment: BasicShape constructor for a rectangle
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape

values.name: renderTransparent
values.comment:
This can be used inside `veryCustom` instead of `WebGL.entity`.
It's a customized blend function that works well with textures with alpha.
values.type: WebGL.Shader attributes uniforms varyings -> WebGL.Shader {} uniforms varyings -> WebGL.Mesh attributes -> uniforms -> WebGL.Entity

values.name: ring
values.comment: BasicShape constructor for a ring
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape

values.name: shape
values.comment: A colored shape, great for prototyping
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape -> { o | color : Color.Color, position : Game.Helpers.Float2, size : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: shapeWithOptions
values.comment: A colored shape, that can also be rotated
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape -> { o | color : Color.Color, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, rotation : Float, pivot : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: shapeZ
values.comment: The same, but with 3d position.
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape -> { o | color : Color.Color, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: sprite
values.comment: A sprite.
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float2, size : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: spriteWithOptions
values.comment:
A sprite with tiling and rotation.

    spriteWithOptions {config | tiling = (3,5)}

will create a sprite with a texture that repeats itself 3 times horizontally and 5 times vertically.
TODO: picture!
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2, tiling : Game.Helpers.Float2, rotation : Float, pivot : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: spriteZ
values.comment: A sprite with 3d position
values.type: { o | texture : Maybe.Maybe WebGL.Texture, position : Game.Helpers.Float3, size : Game.Helpers.Float2 } -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

values.name: toWebGl
values.comment:
Converts a Renderable to a WebGL.Entity.
You don't need this unless you want to slowly introduce
this library in a project that currently uses WebGL directly.

    toWebGl time camera (w, h) renderable
values.type: Float -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> Game.Helpers.Float2 -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable -> WebGL.Entity

values.name: triangle
values.comment: BasicShape constructor for a triangle
values.type: Game.TwoD.Render.BasicShape

values.name: veryCustom
values.comment:
This allows you to specify your own attributes, vertex shader and fragment shader by using the WebGL library directly.
If you use this you have to calculate the transformations yourself. (You can use Shaders.makeTransform)

If you need a square as attributes, you can take the one from Game.TwoD.Shapes

    veryCustom (\{camera, screenSize, time} ->
        WebGL.entity myVert myFrag Shapes.unitSquare
          { u_crazyFrog = frogTexture
          , transform = Shaders.makeTransform (x, y, z) 0 (2, 4) (0, 0)
          , cameraProj = Camera.view camera screenSize
          }
    )
values.type: ({ camera : Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera , screenSize : ( Float, Float ) , time : Float } -> WebGL.Entity) -> Game.TwoD.Render.Renderable

name: Game.TwoD.Camera

types.name: Camera
types.comment:
A camera represents how to render the virtual world.
It's essentially a transformation from virtual game coordinates to pixel coordinates on the screen.

values.name: custom
values.comment:
The custom camera allows you to use a function
that maps viewport size (in pixel) to game units.
E.g. here's an implementation of the fixedWidth camera using custom:

    fixedWidth width =
        custom (\(w, h) -> (width, width * h / w))
values.type: (( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float )) -> ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: fixedArea
values.comment:
A camera that always shows the same area.
This is useful in a top down game.
You probably want to specify the area as a multiplication of width and height:

    fixedArea (16*10) (x, y)

This means the camera will always show 160 square units of your game.
In practice, this means that on a 16:10 viewport, 16 by 10 units of your game will be visible.
But on a 4:3 viewport it would show 14.6 by 10.95 units. (sqrt(16*10*4/3)=14.6, sqrt(16*10*3/4)=10.95)
values.type: Float -> ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: fixedHeight
values.comment:
A camera that always shows `height` units of your game vertically.
Well suited for a vertical scroller.
values.type: Float -> ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: fixedWidth
values.comment:
A camera that always shows `width` units of your game horizontally.
Well suited for a side-scroller.
values.type: Float -> ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: follow
values.comment:
Smoothly follow the given target. Use this in your tick function.

    follow 1.5 dt target camera
values.type: Float -> Float -> ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: getPosition
values.type: Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> ( Float, Float )

values.name: getViewSize
values.comment: Given the screen size, gets the width and height in game units
values.type: ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> ( Float, Float )

values.name: moveBy
values.comment: Move a camera by the given vector *relative* to the camera.
values.type: ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: moveTo
values.comment: Move a camera to the given location. In *absolute* coordinates.
values.type: ( Float, Float ) -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera

values.name: view
values.comment:
Gets the transformation that represents how to transform the camera back to the origin.
The result of this is used in the vertex shader.
values.type: Game.TwoD.Camera.Camera -> ( Float, Float ) -> Math.Matrix4.Mat4

name: Game.TwoD.Shaders
comment:
# Standard shaders for WebGL rendering.

You don't need this module,
unless you want to write your own vertex or fragment shader
and a shader from here already provides one half.

Or if you're using WebGL directly.


## Vertex shaders

@docs vertColoredShape, vertTexturedRect, vertParallaxScroll


## Fragment shaders

@docs fragTextured, fragAnimTextured, fragManualAnimTextured, fragUniColor, fragUniColorCircle, fragUniColorRing

---


### useful helper functions

@docs colorToRGBAVector, colorToRGBVector, makeTransform

values.name: colorToRGBAVector
values.type: Color.Color -> Math.Vector4.Vec4

values.name: colorToRGBVector
values.type: Color.Color -> Math.Vector3.Vec3

values.name: fragAnimTextured
values.comment:
A shader to render spritesheet animations.
It assumes that the animation frames are in one horizontal line
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | texture : WebGL.Texture, bottomLeft : Math.Vector2.Vec2, topRight : Math.Vector2.Vec2, numberOfFrames : Int, duration : Float, time : Float } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: fragManualAnimTextured
values.comment: Same as the shader above, but controlled via frame number instead of time
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | texture : WebGL.Texture, bottomLeft : Math.Vector2.Vec2, topRight : Math.Vector2.Vec2, numberOfFrames : Int, currentFrame : Int } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: fragTextured
values.comment:
Display a tiled texture.
TileWH specifies how many times the texture should be tiled.
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | texture : WebGL.Texture, tileWH : Math.Vector2.Vec2 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: fragUniColor
values.comment: A very simple shader, coloring the whole area in a single color
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | color : Math.Vector3.Vec3 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: fragUniColorCircle
values.comment: A fragment Shader for rendering a single colored circle
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | color : Math.Vector3.Vec3 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: fragUniColorRing
values.comment: A fragment Shader for rendering a transparent circle with a colored border
values.type: WebGL.Shader {} { u | color : Math.Vector3.Vec3 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: makeTransform
values.comment:
Creates a transformation matrix usually used in the fragment shader.

    makeTransform ( x, y, z ) rotation ( w, h ) ( px, py )
values.type: Game.Helpers.Float3 -> Float -> Game.Helpers.Float2 -> Game.Helpers.Float2 -> Math.Matrix4.Mat4

values.name: vertColoredShape
values.comment:
The most basic shader, renders a basic shape.
Since it doesn't even pass along the texture coordinates,
it's only use is to create a colored shape.
values.type: WebGL.Shader Game.TwoD.Shapes.Vertex { a | transform : Math.Matrix4.Mat4, cameraProj : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: vertParallaxScroll
values.comment:
A shader that scrolls it's texture when the camera moves, but at not at the same speed.
Good for background images.
values.type: WebGL.Shader Game.TwoD.Shapes.Vertex { u | cameraPos : Math.Vector2.Vec2, cameraSize : Math.Vector2.Vec2, scrollSpeed : Math.Vector2.Vec2, z : Float, offset : Math.Vector2.Vec2 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

values.name: vertTexturedRect
values.comment:
A simple shader that passes the texture coordinates along for the fragment shader.
Can be generally used if the fragment shader needs to display texture(s).
values.type: WebGL.Shader Game.TwoD.Shapes.Vertex { u | transform : Math.Matrix4.Mat4, cameraProj : Math.Matrix4.Mat4 } { vcoord : Math.Vector2.Vec2 }

name: Game.TwoD.Shapes

aliases.name: Vertex
aliases.comment:
Just an alias for a 2d vector.
Needs to be in a record because it will be passed as an
attribute to the vertex shader

values.name: unitSquare
values.comment: A square with corners (0, 0), (1, 1)
values.type: WebGL.Mesh Game.TwoD.Shapes.Vertex

values.name: unitTriangle
values.comment: A triangle with corners (0, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0)
values.type: WebGL.Mesh Game.TwoD.Shapes.Vertex
